ParentCompanyName: Farmers Feed and Grain Company, Inc.
SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Dept of Ag and Land Stewardship

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan-Executive Summary

Facility: Farmers Feed & grain Company, Inc., Rockford, IA

Contact: Kevin Stewart

Phone: 319-830-1411

1. Facility Policy.

The owners, management and employees of Farmers Feed & Grain Company, Inc. are committed to the

prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur,

the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Floyd County Emergency Management Agency, 

and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.

2. Facility Information.

The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to farmers. The fertilizer

product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient

for crop production. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.

3. The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternate Release Scenario

An analysis of the potential off-site consequences of hypothetical worst-case and alternative-case

accidental releases have been addressed in our Hazard Assessment and information is in our Risk

Management Program.

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health

Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and our

state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia. The OSHA standard is referenced in this RMP

Registration Form; see Section 8.3 (b).

5. Five-Year Accident History.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that

have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge,

has THERE BEEN ANY ACCIDENTAL RELEASES resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations,

property damage, or environmental damage.

6. Emergency Action Plan.

The facility has:

a. A written emergency action plan, in accordan

ce with OSHA standard

29 CFR 1910.38;

b. Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and

Community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

c. If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required

response action is to evacuate the area of the release and call 911 and all applicable emergency 

response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to 

assess the conditions of the facility. There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding 

storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
